comments.body: This is a great idea for players like me who often craft the wrong items.

On second thought, there might already be a mod for this but still, having it be in the base game so that no one has to download mods would be nice.
what if you drink them

If the player drank one of them, they would've had the scent affecting mobs but not themselves. In fact, players would be unaffected by all scents. I could've done a better job making that clear, sorry.
I think this is a great idea.
I think that dragon scales would actually be what you need to upgrade elytra to give it armor points and increased durability.
It has potential
Also, it is worth considering the idea of generating thinner tree trunks.
that would ruin the point of it, then you could just tower and kill, your not suppsoed to be able to do that
And after this you can check out my other ideas. Which are Ender Armor/Tools Insane PvP, A desert overhaul, Quilted wool, Lava cavern, and frozen cave. But the Quilted wool has terrible phrasing.

In my opinion, this would an overpowered solution unless...

it is made up of a lot of components and these components would be extremely rare.
Ok, I saw a different post with only 8 echo shards and said in comments maybe disc 11 in the middle.
Not possible, the disc 11 is a creative mode item
Um, I hate to correct the above comment, but disc 11 is NOT a creative-only item.

With renewable gravel, you can get renewable dirt anyway by making coarse dirt and Hoeing it.

Renewable lava is probably not going to happen, because it means easy infinite obsidian, unless the crucible is made with netherite and powered by end rods or something like that.

Good idea with the sand and gravel though, I would really like to see that in the game, because then skyblock would get much easier, and dirt would be renewable.

Why not have lava have the same renewability as water? Although I don't see why we can't use the grindstone block for this?

 

In all honesty it be easier to just trade for the stuff with villagers. If there was a villager that specialized in selling such blocks than you wouldn't need the generators
Technically, gravel and clay are renewable through some rather unorthodox methods... clay by Mason villagers after a raid, and gravel through piglin bartering.

I agree with 385570477572. With renewable gravel, you could have infinite dirt with the coarse dirt method. Another solution to having infinite dirt would be to craft clay and sand together to get dirt. This would be a much simpler process than getting dirt from the composter. Also, it doesn't delete the renewable bonemeal feature.

While yes, much of these are technically renewable with villager/wandering trader trades and the upcoming piglin bartering, these systems are not practical for renewability on a large scale, nor does it make these resources truly renewable from a production sense.

For example, the podzol and sand trades from the wandering trader are limited in how much you can obtain from the trader at any visit, and are not guaranteed to be options for trade when the trader visits. The clay trade that the mason has (only in Java), as well as the upcoming piglin gravel barter, are trades that are rather late-game and resource intensive to obtain compared to what you get from them. Unless you are swimming in gold and emeralds, they're not very good for what you get from them.

Renewable lava does not in any way have to make obsidian easier to obtain, as obsidian being able to be made from the crucible interface is not a requirement. If Mojang wanted to do that, then they are free to do so, but they do not have to. Lava would still have to be placed, turned into obsidian and then mined. The lava production itself doesn't have to have a fast pace either, if that is also a concern.

The historical real-life function of the grind stone is to sharpen weapons and tools, and is simply not equipped to crush materials. It would be like trying to use sandpaper on a rock to make sand.

The whole purpose of offering the compost option is to not remove the renewable bonemeal function of the composter, while still being able to produce dirt from it. While yes, you wouldn't get white dye, you can make a mob grinder to get easy bones, and bonemeal is not a realistic product from composting.

The available methods for obtaining these resources renewably are not practical for obtaining them in massive amounts, at least not until very late in the game for a few, but not all. These methods are also not intuitive to the average player, and with many real-life examples we can take inspiration from, there is no reason for these basic resources to be unrenewable in terms of actual crafting and production.
With the 1.17 update, all of these have been made renewable, this post is now obsolete :)
Congratulations! Now all we need is renewable sand.

Dirt, Clay, Gravel, and Lava have all now been made renewable as of 1.19.  However, Sand (while technically renewable via wandering trader) is not practical for large quantities without digging up a desert (which not everyone wants to do).  I agree that Cobblestone and any stone crafted stairs/slabs/walls should be grindable into gravel (if it worked like a furnace where it could funnel stuff in and create gravel, that would be great)!  And similarly, then you could also grind gravel finer down into sand which would make sand very renewable (not sure how it is any more fun for sand NOT to be renewable nor does having a renewable source of sand seem OP other than being able to build more with Glass which again seems like it would add fun rather than the feel bad of accidentally breaking valuable Glass or losing valuable Sand).  It could require diamonds or some other rare material in order to make if it feels unbalanced but doesn't seem any more unbalanced than turning wood into charcoal...  TNT can already be duped so that also shouldn't detract and most players aren't crafting tons of TNT in their single player worlds...
I think that by surrounding the Blackstone in and crafting table with the ingots is enough, or just four in a cross pattern. I don't feel like the smithing table is the best place to do it

I agree that it should be craftable. As it stands now, it is too rare. I think it should be crafted in a crafting table though a-posed to the smithing table. Perhaps the recipe can be a Blackstone surrounded by gold nuggets.

I was thinking about crafting it in a crafting table with gold nuggets and blackstone. But a Smithing Table is a much more creative idea as gilded is defined as to coat thinly with gold leaf or paint. Isn't that what we do to our diamond tools and armor? We technically just coat it with netherite. So making a Gilded Blackstone is just imbuing it with gold. A blackstone upgraded with a gold ingot to get a gilded blackstone.
or like 5 nuggets
I think the shulker plate armor should spawn back at the end gateway you came through, when it falls in the Void.
Armor does kinda make sense,but i would think it would just be the helmet,because the shulker shell is literally a helmet,but this is a good idea
What if you never lose it in your inventory

I like the idea for the shulker plate armor. However, because of its defensive property, it should have more defense instead of making the player lighter. The shulker mob makes the levitation, not the shell itself.
It could just be a dyable helmet that looks like a Netherite Helmet
I have no words this would be amazing!

Sounds cool! We're overdue for a jungle overhaul anyway; Id love to see this and some other ideas about the jungle implemented.
Interesting. Maybe needs a tweak, but I like where you are going.
We need this

I was going to suggest the same thing, but you suggested it better!  Charred wood, with a distinctive texture, could really make the aftermath of forest and building fires look more devastated, even as more blocks survive, and it would make abandoned villages look more ruined.  It could also be used to create future structures like ruins or burned villages.  In creative and adventure, charred wood would make a great block for dystopias and war zones.

This is a great idea.

I wouldn't personally go with the gravity version of charred wood (maybe there could be a gravity version that is as if it was charred to powder and on the verge of being completely ash; maybe actually ash), and I would be happy if charred wood was a single product of whatever wood type was burnt, instead of a charred variant for every wood type. Charred wood is black right.

If fire burns wood on one side then it is charred. If the fire is sustained by something else or if fire has spread to more than one side, then it is burnt up.
I had this same idea on my own last night! I was thinking the same thing - that it would drop charcoal unless mined with silk touch. I would love to have charred wood available as a building block.
Still would be a cool addition, even now after 4 years!
can't you get it with silk touch?
This is pretty much the Netherite block, unless you want this as a cheaper alternative/building variety
Maybe not blast resistant, but a new texture would be great
I could certainly see this as a cheaper building variety, @Jonny Bravo, and it would be a good way to store the scrap if you manage to get a bunch of it and don't have a lot of gold on hand.

i would like to see this because i have soooo much netherite in my survival world and i just have it put away in a chest and i have soooo little gold i actually followed this post to! i was also going to suggest this to but i looked first before i did it oh and i voted it ummmm would it work for beacon pryamid
Because we have honey blocks, they probably won't add colored slime blocks. The rest of the suggestion is really good.
TrojanHorse69, the coloured slime idea is simply to make flying machines nicer to see

What if you could craft mineral blocks from dyes? An example would be crafting cyan dye into malachite. It would be an interesting twist on the relation between dyes and minerals, and a clever way to add new blocks that have color and texture, as well as being a way to consolidate dyes. I imagine that the dye mineral blocks can be crafted back into their respective dyes.

I would prefer the recipe using nether brick blocks. While this isn't as urgent as nether obtained tools and weapons, it would be nice not to have to go to the overworld to get a furnace. I like the speed too!
This idea should be implemented, but I agree that it must be able to be created without the need of anything in the overworld.

I agree, but maybe not even in enchantment form, it could just be as a setting in the Options tab, because while this would be useful, I'm not sure if I'd be willing to sacrifice a "slot" on the armor to apply this enchantment.
